title: 114_s2209
content: The Act titled "Lawful Purpose and Self Defense Act" eliminates the authority to reclassify popular rifle ammunition as "armor piercing ammunition." Section 921(a)(17) of title 18, United States Code is amended to clarify the intended use of certain types of ammunition by manufacturers or importers. Elimination of restrictions on importation of non-National Firearms Act firearm or ammunition that may be lawfully possessed and sold in the United States. The amendment eliminates prohibitions on manufacturing or importing armor-piercing ammunition, allowing it for use by the government, exportation, or authorized testing/experimentation. The amendment broadens exceptions in Section 925 of title 18, United States Code, allowing for lawful personal use of firearms or ammunition by members or clubs. It also streamlines the process for authorizing firearm or ammunition importation into the United States. It also streamlines the process for authorizing firearm or ammunition importation into the United States, with specific conditions for importation such as scientific, research, testing, or experimentation purposes, curio or museum pieces, non-firearms, and non-armor piercing ammunition. It also streamlines the process for authorizing firearm or ammunition importation into the United States, with specific conditions for importation such as scientific, research, testing, or experimentation purposes, curio or museum pieces, non-firearms, and non-armor piercing ammunition. The firearm or ammunition can be imported for use by the United States, a State, or political subdivision, for exportation, if previously taken out of the country, or if defined as a curio or relic by the Attorney General. The Attorney General must permit conditional importation within 30 days for examination and testing. The Attorney General will determine if firearm or ammunition importation is allowed under specific conditions, excluding firearms prohibited by section 922(p). The text chunk discusses amendments to the National Firearms Act and Title 18, United States Code, regarding the classification of shotguns, shotgun shells, and large caliber rifles as "destructive devices." The changes aim to replace language about suitability for sporting purposes with language about lawful purposes. SEC. 5 amends Section 922 of title 18, United States Code to allow temporary interstate transfers for all lawful purposes, removing the requirement for "sporting purposes."
